description: Nikola Petrak receives and reviews the Directorate's urgent request to authorize disruptive security crackdowns against neighborhood assemblies and civic networks as unrest grows.
Nikola quietly blocks approval for the Directorate's crackdown, citing procedural gaps and requesting further clarification, which stalls immediate action and buys time for citizen assemblies.

Without Council interference, informal neighborhood assemblies openly organize civic voting to allocate resources and resolve service issues, replacing failing BCI-based decisions. Public engagement surges.
Directorate loyalists attempt covert disruptions of assemblies; livestreamed citizen footage exposes these actions, sparking mass outrage and forcing Directorate elements to withdraw.

Mutual aid networks thrive. Local leaders coordinate essential food, transit, and welfare support. The Council's authority fades as more citizens trust assemblies, despite ongoing resource challenges and debates over fairness.
